    Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)

    Last Updated March 10, 2020 4:30 pm

    Case Count For Community Members Press Releases Guidance Documents For Providers


    The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) is closely monitoring the COVID-19 outbreak. This respiratory illness, caused by a novel (new) coronavirus, was first identified in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China. Chinese authorities identified this new coronavirus which has resulted in thousands of cases across the globe. There are now 74 international locations reporting cases, including the United States.

    The first case of community transmission of COVID-19 was reported on February 28 in California. 2 cases of community acquired COVID-19 were then reported in Washington on February 29. Additional community acquired cases have since been reported in both California and Washington.

    • Initial deaths from COVID-19 occurred in Washington State. Many of the deaths are related to the COVID-19 outbreak at the Life Care Center skilled nursing facility in King County, Washington.
    • California's first death from COVID-19 was reported on March 4, 2020.
    • CDC travel alert levels have been raised for Italy, Iran, South Korea, and Japan.
    • While CDC considers this a serious public health concern, based on current information, the immediate health risk from COVID-19 to the general American public is considered low at this time.

    The Santa Barbara County Public Health Department (SBCPHD) is working closely with the California Department of Public Health and the CDC to respond to the outbreak of this novel coronavirus. California Department of Public Health (CDPH) has activated its Medical and Health Coordinator Center (MHCC).

    SBCPHD has activated its Infectious Disease Emergency Response Plan to prepare for the need to respond to COVID-19 cases. Regular meetings are being held with health care and long-term care providers to plan and coordinate response.

    Testing of persons who meet the clinical criteria for COVID-19 is coordinated between health care providers and the health department. Samples are collected from patients by their health care provider. Testing of the samples is performed at 10 public health laboratories in California, and capacity to test samples is expected to increase as commercial laboratories are scheduled to begin testing in the near future.

    For up-to-date information on the current status of the Coronavirus outbreak:
    CDC: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-in-us.html#reporting-cases
    California: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/OPA/Pages/New-Release-2020.aspx

    TO REPORT CASES

    Providers should call the Disease Control & Prevention Program immediately to report suspect cases of 2019-nCoV.
    • Call 24/7 Phone Line: 805-681-5280
